newsitem.title: USA: Procter & Gamble aims to double business.
newsitem.headline: Procter & Gamble aims to double business.

text.p: Procter & Gamble Co Chairman John Pepper on Friday told analysts that the company plans to double its annual sales to $70 billion by 2006.
He said the company plans to achieve that goal with annual sales growth rates of seven percent, while maintaining earnings growth rates in the range of 11 percent to 14 percent.

At a nearly three-hour New York analysts' meeting, Durk Jager, P&G's president and chief operating officer, said the company plans to make restructuring a routine, ongoing part of the company's approach.
The costs associated with this approach would have no impact on earnings estimates, Jager said.
Procter & Gamble shares fell 3-3/8 to 133-1/8 in an overall stock market selloff Friday morning, but by early afternoon they were up 1-1/4 on the day, to 137-3/4.
Pepper said that $7 billion or $8 billion of the projected sales growth would come in underdeveloped markets, such as Eastern Europe, South America and East Asia.
"We are just scratching the surface of what's possible," he said. "The potential going forward is absolutely phenomenal."
Sales in China will pass the $1 billion mark this year, he added.

Other components of P&G's growth strategy include building on its lead in its four top categories -- laundry, hair care, diapers and feminine hygiene. The company sees adding another $10 billion in sales over the next decade in this area.
New businesses, such as food products with non-fat Olean, are expected to supply another $12 billion in added sales by 2006, Pepper said.
He said Procter & Gamble also will consider more acquisitions, such as its proposed purchase of Tambrands Inc, now awaiting approval from Tambrands shareholders and various regulatory agencies.
